subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: ... Yes, but the same is true if you have Serbian in Cyrillic or Latin script. I assume that you would use a script tag in some way to get the Serbian read out
messageBody:
At 08:35 -0700 2007-11-01, oliver langan wrote:
>>I'd say the real questionable disunification is MIME and NUN from AH and AWE.
>
>As I see it, the main disagreement over shared code points has been
>whether to reuse encodings where the glyphs look and sound the same,
>or if (as you suggest) simply looking the same is sufficient. In
>the latter case, I have a practical question: what of
>computer-generated speech? If there are new code points for AH and
>AWE, despite them having similar glyph shapes, then the
>pronunciation of the characters should be clear (our discussions of
>dialect notwithstanding); if they share code points I would imagine
>there would have to be a higher-level encoding which determines
>whether the computer is reading Shavian or QuickScript.

Yes, but the same is true if you have Serbian in Cyrillic or Latin
script. I assume that you would use a script tag in some way to get
the Serbian read out correctly. If that were the case...

>Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same page?

... then it does seem that Shaw might be supplemented by a Shqw which
the text reader would have to be able to parse. Ranges tagged en_Shaw
and ranges tagged en_Shqw would invoke different speech modules.

Right, John? I mean... I'm not sure I can get the Mac OS for instance
to read anything but English at present.
--
Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com

At 08:35 -0700 2007-11-01, oliver langan wrote:
>>I'd say the real questionable disunification is MIME and NUN from AH and AWE.
>
>As I see it, the main disagreement over shared code points has been 
>whether to reuse encodings where the glyphs look and sound the same, 
>or if (as you suggest) simply looking the same is sufficient.  In 
>the latter case, I have a practical question: what of 
>computer-generated speech?  If there are new code points for AH and 
>AWE, despite them having similar glyph shapes, then the 
>pronunciation of the characters should be clear (our discussions of 
>dialect notwithstanding); if they share code points I would imagine 
>there would have to be a higher-level encoding which determines 
>whether the computer is reading Shavian or QuickScript.

Yes, but the same is true if you have Serbian in Cyrillic or Latin 
script. I assume that you would use a script tag in some way to get 
the Serbian read out correctly. If that were the case...

>Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same page?

... then it does seem that Shaw might be supplemented by a Shqw which 
the text reader would have to be able to parse. Ranges tagged en_Shaw 
and ranges tagged en_Shqw would invoke different speech modules.

Right, John? I mean... I'm not sure I can get the Mac OS for instance 
to read anything but English at present.
